Because of the lateness of the hour, I will conclude my remarks on that point, but we welcome the increase to 2 per cent in local government personal income tax sharing. I hope that the increase will not lead to a complacency whereby it is said: 'Because we give this amount in untied grants we are going to ignore completely the additional responsibilities that have been placed at the grass roots level of government without having due regard to their needs and to the assistance that should be given'.

talk.start.para: - It is with pleasure that I associate myself with the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Amendment Bill which is before the House tonight. For a period of some 35 years I was closely associated with local government in New South Wales, as an employee and later as an alderman and a mayor. I believe that this past service in public office places me in an ideal position to recollect the difficulties that occurred when local government bodies endeavoured to raise the necessary revenue from the ratepayers so that they could adequately provide the necessary services and in many instances additional services to which the ratepayers and residents were justly entitled.
- Who introduced the breakthrough?

- Just wait and listen. I recall very well the persistent local government approaches to government for a share of income tax and the deputation I lead as chairman of the New South Wales Country Mayors Association in 1972. I remember as a delegate the 1972 annual conference of the Local Government Association of New South Wales. It was held in Canberra for one express purpose and that was to place pressure on both the Government of the day and the Opposition to promise yearly untied grants to local government. To the credit of both the Government and the Opposition of the day assurances were given that local government would be assisted. The Canberra conference was the breakthrough that was needed. We all know that the Whitlam Government commenced the allocation of some funds in the 1974-75 financial year. The allocation of funds to local government, I believe, would have happened irrespective of who had been elected in 1972. Local government had made its point and had won the day. Since the election of this Government in 1975 a different atmosphere has surrounded local government. This change has been brought about by an election promise, a promise of which I am pleased to be part as the honourable member for Macquarie. This Government recognised the responsibilities and needs of local government, the government which is closest to the people. The Government is therefore committed to provide to local government throughout Australia a direct share of personal tax collections.

speech.para: The tax formula which now forms the basis of local government funding first became effective in the financial year 1976-77. It then provided in total $ 1 40m to be distributed. This constituted an increase of $60m or about 75 per cent in the funds provided by the previous Labor Government in the preceding financial year. This Government did not stop with just recognition. In the first year of increased financial support it promised to increase the base percentage of personal tax collections from 1 .52 per cent to 2 per cent during the life of this Parliament. Today is the completion of that promise. When one analyses data from federal Budgets during recent years there emerges a most generous trend. During the last four years, the life of the current

Liberal-National Country Party Government, federal funding to local government has increased from $80m to a massive $220m estimated for the current financial year. The passing of this legislation will ensure an increase of $3Om for the 1980-81 financial year.

I know well that the Blue Mountains City Council and Penrith City Council, whose shires form the bulk of my electorate, appreciate our past recognition of their efforts and responsibilities. They will be further delighted by this decision today. It ensures that they, along with all other municipalities and shires throughout Australia, will be able to continue to improve and expand their services to local communities. At the same time, they should be able to keep rate increases well below the inflation rate. I refer briefly to the grants which have been received in the electorate of Macquarie and to what occurred under the previous Government. In 1975-76, under the previous Labor Government, Penrith City Council received $450,000 and the Blue Mountains City Council received $310,000 from a total grant of $80m. It should be recalled, however, that under the guidelines of the previous Government not all local government authorities received a grant. In fact, Oberon Shire Council, whose area was then part of the electorate of Macquarie, did not receive one cent. It received nothing under the previous Government. In 1973 the then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, in his second reading speech on the Grants Commission Bill 1 973, said: . . . the financial assistance to local governing bodies which will flow From the Commission's recommendations will in no way be a substitute for the revenues normally raised by them by long established methods such as rates and charges for services, nor will it replace assistance normally provided by State governments to local governing bodies in one way or another. Rather, it will be in the nature of a 'topping-up' process of the financial resources of lesser endowed bodies to enable them, by reasonable revenue raising efforts on their part, to provide a standard of services to their communities that will be comparable with that enjoyed by communities elsewhere.

In its first report on financial assistance to local government in 1974, the Commission recommended grants for 1974-75 totalling $56,345,000. That sum went to 806 local government bodies and represented 92 per cent of the 876 which applied for assistance. I repeat, the Oberon Shire Council, which was then a part of the electorate of Macquarie, received nothing.

In its second report in 1975-76, the Commission recommended grants totalling $79,908,000 for 845 local government bodies. These represented more than 95 per cent of the 885 which had applied for assistance. Still, at that stage, not every local government body in

Australia received assistance. It should be remembered that, as has been previously stated, not all local government authorities received grants under the former Labor Government. In 1974- 75, 92 per cent received grants and in 1 975- 76 the proportion was 95 percent.

Today the topping up process does not apply. All local government authorities share in this special allocation of funds. This Government's allocation in its first year of office was $140m. This year it totals $222m and, with the additional allocation which represents 2 per cent of income tax revenue, it will rise to $250m in 1980-81. Penrith City Council, which was allocated $800,000 in 1976-77 has received $1,305,000 during this financial year and next year it will receive $1.5m thanks to the Fraser Government. Similarly, the Blue Mountains City Council received $500,000 in 1976-77 and will receive $lm in 1980-81. That is double the amount it received in 1976-77. The grants to both councils must have a stabilising effect on their rate structure.

I wish to refer specifically to the manner in which some councils in New South Wales are spending this untied grant money. There are instances in which it could be used to ease the rate burden but in many cases it is being used to provide services that I believe are not within the ambit of local government. Rather they are within the ambit of the New South Wales Government. Because some councils have gone outside the traditional role of providing public services such as roads, drains, playing fields, libraries, water and sanitation, other councils viewing this from a distance have decided to become part of the act. Today social workers, community workers, youth workers and welfare officers are being employed by local government in increasing numbers. Some bodies have even decided to employ fire officers. As at 1 March 1979, 27 councils in New South Wales employed community workers, 30 employed youth workers and 28 employed welfare officers for the aged. One council employs all of these and has a welfare staff of 27. The officer-in-charge of that staff enjoys a status which is similar to that of a city engineer.

talk.start.para: - Which council is that?

- I refer to Marrickville Council, in Sydney. I point out these facts because of the desire of local government for a still greater share of income tax revenue. Councils that are entering so extensively into the social welfare field should think about it for a while because I believe they are entering a field which is the responsibility of their State government. I support with pleasure the Bill that is before the House.

- I wish to reply briefly to the remarks of the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Gillard), who admitted somewhat grudgingly that the Whitlam Labor Government introduced tax sharing arrangements for local government authorities. It is a fact of life that for many years local government authorities had been seeking federal aid. Our Government undertook an inquiry and made its first commitment in that regard in 1974-75.That commitment was increased by 40 per cent in Labor's last year in office to $79.9m. Frankly, the honourable member for Macquarie should also know that Labor introduced many other broad programs which assisted local government. One of the programs which helped particularly in the Macquarie area was the national sewerage program. That program has been completely abolished by the present Government. I will reveal figures to show that this Government has cut funds for local government by 20 per cent in real terms since Labor's last year in office. I make it clear that the Labor Party is committed to sharing with local government at least 2 per cent of federal personal income tax raised. As I said earlier, the Labor Party first introduced grants to local government without any strings attached. To that extent, the Opposition is not opposed to this Bill, as far as it goes.

speech.para: However, the Bill does not go far enough. The Labor Party regards local government as potentially the most active level of government where people can participate in the process of improving their living environment and of exercising some control over the decisions that affect them in their daily lives. The Opposition does not believe that any one level of government can resolve the many problems facing Australians. The three levels of government have to work together in co-operation as equal partners to improve living standards. I was the Minister responsible for local government between 1972 and 1975. The whole role of the Labor Government was to seek to work in a co-operative way in urban and local government affairs. The only way those problems could be solved was to have the Australian, State and local governments working together. We had to break down the differences that existed and start to build a respect and understanding between the public servants, or what I call the bureaucracies. Until the differences between the bureaucracies can be broken down so that there can be planning and an accepted interrelationship, there will never be true government in this country.

This Government's approach to local government is narrow and aloof. It does not regard local government as a real partner in the co-operative system. It treats local government as an appendage and has reduced the relationship to a mere flow of money. I wish to make it clear that this

Government has not increased- rather it has reduced- the total real funds available to local government. To give some proof of this I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing Federal funding for local government between 1975-76- the last year of a Federal Labor government- and 1979-80.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: -I thank the House. The table shows that the total Commonwealth payments to the States for local government at 1979-80 prices fell from $476.6m in 1975-76 to $382.7m in 1979-80-a cutback of 20 per cent. In 1975-76 payments to the States for local government made up 4.5 per cent of total individual income tax revenue collected by the Federal Government in the previous year, but in 1979-80 they made up only 2.9 per cent. Even if the payments for roads and the Regional Employment Development scheme- which the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has criticised- are excluded, the proportion of payments for local government under the same period fell from 2.2 per cent to 1.9 per cent. The reductions were made in direct and other payments to local government, which were cut from$188.3 in 1975-76 to $27min 1979-80.1 seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which is drawn from Budget Paper No. 7 for 1979-80.

speech.para: Leave granted. The table read as follows-

talk.start.para: -I thank the House. That table $188m in 1975-76 to $27m in 1979-80. These clearly reveals that the Government has failed specific purpose programs allowed for the the community. The figures in that table prove sharing of ideas, experimentation with programs that specific purpose payments have been with- and the on-going contact between people indrawn or cut drastically from an amount ofvolved in the three levels of government. They were directed to the specific needs of the people. In the second reading speech the Treasurer said that the RED Scheme and employment grants passed on to local government authorities by the States 'were merely used as a channel for disbursement of funds to assist employment'. This Government is very reluctant to assist employment. But the Treasurer shows no understanding of how the RED Scheme worked- the important socially useful work that was done in local areas, the networks that were created in local areas and the employment that was generated. I point out that in Labor's new proposal which was put forward on Sunday by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden), we do not intend to follow fully the former RED Scheme.

speech.para: In relation to the programs of the RED Scheme, I want to make this point clearly: I was one of the RED Ministers, if I may use that term. I have always been 'red' in my politics. I always try to adopt a humane approach. Let me place on the record that the RED Scheme was not abolished by a Federal Labor Government. Funds were made available. In a submission to the Cabinet, the responsible Minister of the day, Senator James McClelland as he then was, put forward a proposal to clean up the RED Scheme at a cost of $ 124m. The Cabinet decided to provide $135m. The reason for the difference of $1 lm in the allocation was so that the program could continue at least until 1 January 1976. If the employment position did not improve as a result of budgetary action it was planned to stimulate the economy by creating further employment opportunities through the RED Scheme. What happened was that the bureaucracy of the Department of Labour at that time said after the Budget figures had been determined that an error had been made in its figures and it was not able to meet the commitment. The Department of Labour was inefficient in its costing. However, the Budget commitment had been made. I want to make it quite clear now that at no time- I emphasise 'at no time'- did a Federal Labor Cabinet finalise the RED Scheme. I make that point clear as a Cabinet Minister of the day.

Let me illustrate some achievements under the RED program. I come from the western suburbs of Sydney. Under the RED program some very socially useful projects were completed. I invite honourable members to look at some of the projects. They included a botanical garden at West Auburn, the central gardens at Merrylands, the improvements carried out along Duck River, a tributary of the Parramatta River, and the improvements carried out in many urban parks. Mr Deputy Speaker, you come from Western

Australia. Some of the finest works programs have been carried out in the suburbs of Perth in the Belmont Shire because of the initiative of local government. It has been very fine work. I am not saying that errors were not made; they were made. But governments have to learn from the mistakes that have been made. We have to make sure that members of this Parliament start to have some compassion about creating employment. Certainly the RED Scheme performed a very useful social function. It created a great deal of good and a great deal of employment. The priority of allowing local government the real opportunity to promote ongoing employment and to improve local areas is an important priority which a Labor government will be committed to when it is elected at the end of this year as it was committed in the past.

Let us consider some of the special purpose programs that have been curtailed by this Government and its blanket approach to local government funding. For instance, money flowing to aged or disabled persons homes, handicapped persons assistance, child care facilities, homeless persons assistance, senior citizens centres, employment grants, growth centre funding, area improvement programs within local government areas, the National Estate, the national sewerage program, urban public transport and regional development assistance has been either curtailed drastically or, in most cases, completely abolished. All of these programs were aimed at improving the living standards and lives of people.

The ability of local government bodies to meet these needs out of general revenue grants is being reduced also by the increase in interest rates. Local government bodies will find it increasingly difficult to raise sufficient funds for essential community services because of the increase in interest rates that will occur. Recently the Loan Council approved an increase of 0.8 per cent in semi-government borrowings. In November 1977 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) made an election commitment that the Government would reduce interest rates by 2 per cent by the end of the year. But the interest rate for securities of terms of less than 10 years has increased from 10 per cent at that time to 11.6 per cent in March 1980. Over the same period interest rates for long term securities have risen from 10.3 per cent to 1 1.7 per cent. Those authorities involved in the provision of publicly subsidised infrastructure- electricity, ports, roads- for private corporations will get preferential treatment in capital in finance markets.

On the question of raising moneys, local government authorities now have to pay 1 1.7 per cent interest to borrow money in order to carry out these programs. The private sector may get 12 per cent debentures. Companies service the interest debt on debentures before the 42.5 per cent company tax is charged. Therefore 12 per cent debentures cost these corporations less than 7 per cent interest. So the private sector is developing works paying only 7 per cent interest on the money borrowed while local government authorities have to pay up to 11.7 per cent. Again, this is one of the unfair burdens that this Government has imposed.

Local government bodies will be increasingly forced to redistribute the cost of providing community services on to the individual through the various techniques known generally as the user pays system. Such a redistribution will be inequitable. Those regions most in need of improved services will least be able to afford them. If Federal Government funding is allocated to local government on an unweighted per capita basis, as the Grants Commission has proposed, the inequities will be even greater. This Government gives priority to those programs which provide public subsidies to private corporations for the development of industrial infrastructure. The Government is guilty of neglecting the needs of people. For example, recently I visited the Queensland city of Gladstone where there is large-scale corporate investment in alumina refining and aluminium smelting. A lot of public money is being used in Gladstone to provide transport facilities for companies, upgrading the rail systems, expansion of port facilities, improvement of roads to allow heavy traffic and provision of excessively cheap electricity at around 0.5 cents per kilowatt hour to Comalco when the normal average Australian citizen pays something like 3c per kilowatt hour, or in other words, a cost something like six times greater than that paid by Comalco. However, the schools are overcrowded, there is a critical housing shortage, there is only one welfare officer operating on a shoestring budget, health facilities are inadequate and there are few recreational facilities. The social problems in Gladstone are increasing with the rapid expansion of industry, but those social problems are not being adequately addressed. There are many people of goodwill on the local council and in the community generally who would be willing to work to make Gladstone a more reasonable environment in which to live if they were given some encouragement and assistance. Those are just some of the things that affect local government.

In conclusion, I point out that apart from the 2 per cent general revenue assistance to local government, a Labor government will introduce a broad program to assist local government. I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard the local government policy set out at the Labor Party's conference in Adelaide.
Leave granted.

quote.para: LOCAL GOVERNMENT
Labor is committed to the recognition of local government- as a genuine recognised partner in the Australian Government system, with rights and responsibilities.

In state constitutions, as autonomous, with its own bona ride electorate, and with its own revenue sharing responsibilities. Which ought not be suspended by another level of government without formal rules and proper enquiries, hearings and appeals.

As a general (multi-) purpose personal level of government which ought to have a role which is not strictly limited, and given permission only to undertake a limited range of activities. It should be positively encouraged to include selected enterprises and use its initiative.
And to its representation on the Council for InterGovernmental Relations. It should be actively involved in inter-governmental consultations and agreements, especially those affecting it financially.
And will seek the support of local government for the inclusion of a local government representative on the Loan Council and for power of the Australian Government to borrow on its behalf.

Labor recognises three fundamentals about our Federal System of government, namely that- 1 Within a three-level government system there is a need to balance the functions and finances of each level to ensure the adequate development of services and natural and human resources. 2 Between the three levels there ought to be consultation, co-operation and joint evaluation of public programmes. 3 The three levels of government need to be involved in setting priorities and broad targets for the standards and quality of community services and conditions that their combined efforts are aimed at producing.

Consensus on Local Government Responsibilities4 Labor believes that local government should have its authority and responsibilities more clearly defined recognising the need for diversity between States. A Labor Government will therefore promote and participate in a discussion and inquiry into the desirable range of functions, rating and revenue raising, principles of organisation and operation, and the principles of inter-government relations, for modern local government. This inquiry would be undertaken with states, local government and community organisations.

Revenue Sharing and Local Government 5Labor is committed to sharing with local government at least 2 per cent of the federal personal income tax of the previous year. In the event of the real value of federal net personal income tax collections ever falling between the years, a Labor Government will maintain at least the real value level of the previous year, i.e., the provision of general (untied) revenue assistance to local councils by a proportion of the revenue raised by the national government.

Principles of Division of the Revenue Sharing Grants 6 The major factors to be considered in reaching recommendations on revenue grant levels between all local government authorities will include the following- a a capitation grant comprising 30 per cent of all revenue sharing funds will be given to all councils; b a second part, a 'needs' or 'topping up' component will be added to the capitation grant based on the following criteria, which would comprise the other 70 per cent of revenue sharing grants- i assessment of disabilities in the revenue base or capacities of the area; ii assessment of expenditure, disabilities, such as the characteristics of the council area's demography, topography, geography and geology; and iii assessment of the relative needs of the area 's population and the level of services available to them (especially those provided by the Council).
The Australian Grants Commission7 Will be responsible for calling for applications for general revenue grants. It will report publicly on its advice to the Australian Government.
S The Grants Commission panels examining Councils' needs in each State will include State and local government nominees. Provision will be made to receive public submissions.

Local Government and Special Purpose Grants9 In addition to its commitment to general revenue assistance by revenue sharing, Labor is committed to assisting local government by special purpose grants to be allocated on a needs basis. 10 These grants will absorb a number of existing special purpose grants, into a series of broadly based grants with greater discretion at the local level. 1 1 These special purpose grants will give priority to regional and community development activities, and programmes to alleviate the growing unemployment problem. 12 In addition, special assistance will be given to assist cooperative activities between local government bodies on a regional basis.

talk.start.para: -I thank the House. I want to refer specifically to some of the headings under which the broad program is set out. Under the heading 'Consensus on Local Government Responsibilities ', and I wish to read this because an ongoing inquiry is so necessary due to the differences from State to State, it is stated:

quote.para: Labor believes that local government should have its authority and responsibilities more clearly defined recognising the need for diversity between States. A Labor Government will therefore promote and participate in a discussion and inquiry into the desirable range of functions, rating and revenue raising, principles of organisation and operation, and the principles of inter-government relations, for modern local government. This inquiry would be undertaken with states, local government and community organisations.

speech.para: This would be an ongoing inquiry because it is extremely important to get a better understanding of local government. Only with that understanding will Federal, State and local governments be able to work together to make local government a more" functioning authority. This Government has failed to do that. It provides local government authorities with moneys without any real co-operation and without any real understanding of its programs.

talk.start.para: -Like the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Gillard), it has been my lot to be a member of local government for 36 years. During that time I have seen the great changes that have taken place in this form of government, going more or less from the horse and buggy days to the modern age of machinery and development. The Bill before the House is to amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976 to increase the annual percentage of net personal income tax collections allocated to local government from 1.75 per cent to 2 per cent as from the 1980-81 financial year.

speech.para: Under the Liberal-National Country Party federalism policy which commenced in 1976-77, local government receives a fixed percentage share of the net personal income tax collections of the previous year. For 1976-77, 1977-78 and 1978-79 the percentage share of this personal income tax revenue was 1.52 per cent. The Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Amendment Act 1979 raised the share to 1.75 per cent for this period. This Bill provides for the percentage share to be raised by 2 per cent as from 1980-81. This fulfils an undertaking given by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in his November 1977 election policy speech that the local government share of income tax collections would be raised to 2 per cent. The tax sharing funds, like the general revenue grants for local government provided in 1974-75 and 1975-76 under the Australian Labor Party Government, are not subject to any conditions as to how they may be spent by local authorities.

Untied funds for local government have increased substantially in recent years. It is entirely up to the local government body how these untied grants are allocated. Some councils in their wisdom enter into new projects. Other councils use the grants for assistance with rates. Also there are many other avenues to which local government allocates these funds. I mentioned that these funds have risen substantially in recent years. The allocations were $80m in 1975-76, $140m in 1976-77, $165m in 1977-78, $179m in 1978-79 and $222m in 1979-80. It is anticipated in this Bill that we are debating at present that the amount wil be approximately $303m in this financial year. The distribution among States of the total share of income tax collections earmarked for local government is set out in the principal Act. Distribution between local government authorities, of course, is decided by each
State grants commission. I add that the State governments also allocate funds to their various local governments.

talk.start.para: - I do not think they give anywhere near enough.

- I am just coming to that matter. The funds they allocate are nothing compared with the Federal Government grants. Personal income tax under this legislation is to be increased from 1.75 per cent to 2 per cent and it is to apply as from the 1980-81 financial year. Local governments in the past 15 years have assumed greater responsibility at the request of the ratepayers. We find that today ratepayers expect swimming pools, baby health centres, sporting ovals, assistance for handicapped children, pensioner centres, libraries, social workers, community halls, kindergartens and so on. Local governments are also expected to and do carry out decentralisation of industries in their areas. Here they are assisted by the State governments. In New South Wales, the allocation is 60 per cent to State government, 30 per cent to local government and 10 per cent to the industry concerned. Local government in this State has made a great contribution to bringing industries into country areas. Of course, this has meant an added burden to the ratepayers. Local government rates right throughout Australia have reached saturation point. There is no doubt that local government bodies require assistance from both the State governments and the Federal Government, but under the Constitution local government is to be administered and financed entirely by the State government. It is only in recent years that the Federal Government has entered this field. We find now that the grants that are being made under this legislation are a very important part of local government finance throughout Australia. The shire clerks are getting their councils' estimates ready and this Bill has been introduced at a most opportune time.

speech.para: Local government bodies have also taken over the trusteeships of showgrounds and recreation areas and are assisting with funds for unemployment. The Federal Government allocates funds to the various States. The Wran Government in New South Wales received $ 16m before the end of 1979. It is up to that Government to make some of these funds available for unemployment purposes. We find that the State governments are making these funds available but local government has to find money on a dollar for dollar basis in this area. Here again, of course, this places a burden on local government. One often wonders whether local government is endeavouring to take on too much financial responsibility in the social service field. Many country local governing bodies as well as their city counterparts have a social service department, a social worker and an assistant. I feel that social welfare should be the responsibility of the State governments. This area of responsibility should not be foisted onto the local government bodies. It should be a responsibility of the State governments.

In New South Wales at the present time the Labor Government is hell bent on the amalgamation of shire councils and municipal councils right, left and centre. The reason it gives for the amalgamation of these councils is that it is a saving, that it is an economic measure. The New South Wales Grants Commission which is recommending the amalgamation of these councils cannot give one instance where an amalgamation has saved the ratepayer one cent. As a matter of fact, it goes the other way. Costs are increased and staff of both shire and municipal councils, when an amalgamation takes place, have to be employed for a period of two years. The chief administration of some of these local governing bodies is up for something like $120,000 a year over the amalgamations before passing on to the engineering department and the other departments of the local government bodies concerned. This is an absolutely ridiculous situation. The honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) has spoken about the Regional Employment Development scheme which was in operation during the time that the Labor Government was in power here in Canberra. The RED scheme was quite all right where it involved a worthwhile project, where it employed labour and where there was adequate supervision. If there was no supervision of a RED scheme project, many times the money was wasted. Where there was supervision the results of the projects were excellent.

In relation to local government finance, capital funds are not the problem of local government bodies. Plenty of loan funds are available for local government to carry out schemes. Indeed, in New South Wales at the present time, the local government rate on borrowings is of the order of 12 per cent. Of course, when local government borrows funds for various works in its area there comes a day of reckoning and these borrowings have to be repaid. This is an added burden for the ratepayers.

Local government bodies receive not only assistance from us and State governments but also road funds which are made available to them by the Federal Government. They receive grants for libraries and grants towards many other facets of their particular type of government. In my electorate of Paterson we have something like 1 8 local government bodies. Some of them are shire councils, some of them are municipal councils and several of them, of course, are provincial city councils. It has been mentioned by the honourable member for Reid that this increase in local government funding to 2 per cent is one of the few promises fulfilled by the Fraser Government. This is a promise that is fulfilled by that Government, but it is not the only promise that has been fulfilled by the Government. Many other promises have been fulfilled by this FraserAnthony Government.

It has been said by previous speakers that local government is the closest to the people. There is no doubt about that. The people in these areas expect a lot from local government. So the Government is making additional funds available under this Bill to enable local governments throughout New South Wales to carry out their duties and to assist the ratepayers who, I have said, are burdened with very high rates today. The rates have reached saturation point. The ratepayers are surely entitled to some assistance. As mentioned previously, it is still the responsibility of the various State governments in Australia to look after the financing of local governments. It is only in the past few years that the Federal Government has come into this field, with great benefit to local governments concerned. It is a great pleasure to support this legislation which will be of tremendous benefit to local government throughout Australia and which will be welcomed by all those councils concerned.

talk.start.para: -The honourable member for Paterson (Mr O'Keefe) was referring to functions and responsibilities which are undertaken by local government and which ought not be the responsibility of local government. I think that there are examples of local government being quite unfairly asked to take on responsibilities- for example, in cases of major developmental projects. I am thinking of the development of an aluminium smelter by Alcoa of Australia Ltd in the city of Portland, Victoria, in the electorate of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), Wannon. In that situation, where a private company is in the process of making a major investment which will be presumably a very profitable investment, local government has been asked, and I believe has agreed, to provide a concession of the order of 50 per cent in rates for that company. It seems to me that that represents quite an inappropriate case of local government forgoing revenue for the sake of the development of a company which in turn will put considerable pressure on that local government area to provide the range of services that will be necessary for that company and for the infrastructure which will service that development.

speech.para: Speaking for the moment on behalf of my electorate, which is located in the north-eastern corridor of Melbourne, I think that one has, in the first instance, to recognise that it was the Labor Government which not only initiated the provision of direct funding for local government, which has certainly been very much appreciated by the Preston, Northcote and Heidelberg councils, which are in my electorate, but also provided a relationship in terms of the way that some of those funds were spent and provided additional funds.

The Government said a great deal about the restoration of local initiative. If there is one comment that I would make about this Government's record as it affects my electorate it is that it has done a great deal to destroy initiative. I refer in the first instance to the development of regional organisations of councils, which was one of the methods by which funds from the Department of Urban and Regional Development were channelled into the area of local government. Region 14, covering those three municipalities and three further municipalities in that north-eastern corridor of Melbourne, was a very effective mechanism.

In the period of office of the Labor Government a number of important initiatives got under way. For example, the Darebin parkland scheme, which is an extremely important example of the conversion of an area of landpartly quarry land and a highly neglected area of the city of Melbourne- into one of the finest parklands was the result of the contribution of a substantial amount of money by the Department of Urban and Regional Development for the acquisition of some of that land for incorporation within the Darebin parklands as they have now become. That initiative has continued. It is an example of the very great co-operation that exists between the Northcote and Heidelberg councils in my electorate.

An area of conservation has been created which is extremely important not only to those two municipalities but also to the whole northeastern corridor of Melbourne. Similarly, when region 14 was in existence and was receiving funds it looked at the social service and social welfare needs not simply on a municipality by municipality basis but in terms of the whole corridor, providing a framework for social planning, which is extremely important, so that the services that are developed within that area are developed with a recognition of what resources and facilities are available in the whole corridor of Melbourne. To some extent the area is shaped by the river and creek systems- the Yarra River, and the Darebin and Merri creeks. Under region 14 a study was undertaken of those waterways and the potential for conservation and development and of the recreational and other purposes that those systems represented.

It would have to be said that the interest of the Commonwealth Government ceased in 1975. Some of those projects have been further developed by the State Government but the Commonwealth Government has ceased to have an interest. When I arranged for a delegation to come to Canberra in 1978 it was quite clear that this Government was not interested in talking to local government directly. Whereas there had been successful delegations in previous years, it became quite clear that local government was simply not welcome by the Government in Canberra for any serious discussions in terms of the problems that those six municipalities, representing something like 300,000 people, faced. I do not believe that the mechanism that the Government has established for inter-governmental cooperation has met that need, which was clearly manifested and demonstrated. The Advisory Council for Inter-Government Relations has been another of the gimmicks. It has no real achievements to its credit. It has not provided a real basis for communication and co-operation between local government and other levels of government. It has produced a few studies, one or two reports, but very little else.

Certainly the climate has changed within the context in which one looks at local government, particularly in terms of urban and regional planning. In the past three or four years there has not been anything like the interest that was shown in the problems of cities and regional areas in the early 1970s or even during the 1960s. But that does not mean that problems that existed at that time and which were highlighted and given attention by the Labor Government have gone away. Indeed, I believe that there is an argument that if anything those problems which were identified in deprived areas of great cities have grown very much worse in the latter part of the 1970s. Of course, that is the product not simply of this Government's neglect of urban problems. It is the product of an economic recession which this Government has fostered and for which it has. been unable to manufacture policies to enable us to escape from. The Government has created, I believe very much as a direct result of its policies, quite massive unemployment within this country, and indeed very much greater unemployment than has ever existed at any previous time in the post-war period. That is undeniable. Figures that might refer simply to the past 12 months or which might be based simply on one or other of the surveys carried out do not contradict that. As the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) pointed out earlier in this debate, unemployment goes well beyond the official figures, and includes those who would prefer to be in full employment but who are now in part time employment, the underemployed. It also includes those who have been discouraged from registering at all, those who have left the work force and who represent a vast reservoir of hidden unemployed.

The relationship between unemployment and this Bill is quite clear in the sense that the Bill refers to income for local government being made through the States. One has to look at that flow of money within the context of wider developments. For example, one has to look at it in terms of the sharp decline in funding for capital spending for the States that has occurred since this Government came to power. In a real sense local government has a responsibility for dealing with externalities, those consequences which flow from the private capitalist system, from a market economy in which the costs tend not to be borne by the private firm but rather by the public sector. Increasingly local government is being asked to bear a greater and greater burden in terms of the social and physical costs of not only a private capitalist system but also a system which is seriously in recession. If one relates that to the failure of the Government to maintain spending on capital works, one can see how serious the problem is.
I want to quote briefly from Russell Mathews' report entitled Australian Federalism 1978. He is referring to 1978-79, but he might be referring even more strongly to 1979-80. He says:

quote.para: Any expansion in development works in 1 978-79 was thus destined to take place at the expense of the already badly run down capital stock of the Australian cities and the country's essential services and transport systems. As noted in Chapter I, it is one of the extraordinary features of Australian economic policies during recent years that a period of high unemployment has coincided with severe restrictions on public sector capital spending.

speech.para: He continues:

quote.para: The failure of the Commonwealth and the States to agree on rational policies for public sector investment and finance has depressing implications for the Australian economy, both in the short term through its effects on employment and in the long term through its effects on standards of essential services and economic growth. In this respect, the history of the Great Depression is being repeated.

speech.para: No one is suggesting that by the provision of funds for local government for job creation and for employment creating purposes all the problems of unemployment that exist in this country would be solved. Nevertheless it is quite clear and it has been made quite clear by the Opposition that a very large number of useful and worthwhile jobs could be created in the local government area. In terms of the problems that my electorate faces, it requires no great imagination to think of useful works that might be carried out in the local government area.

I have referred, for example, to a study which was carried out in 1977 of the waterways systems that run through my electorate. That study suggested a whole series of works which might have been undertaken to resolve the very severe problems of pollution which exist in creeks systems such as the Darebin and Merri Creeks which run through most of the northern areas of the city of Melbourne. Pollution certainly could have been substantially alleviated. Those creek systems could have been made the centre of important recreational areas. It would be possible to develop in parallel with those creeks, for example, bike-ways or forms of tracks that young people and others could use for the purpose even of commuter journeys. Those creek systems run through a whole series of municipalities and provide relatively direct links.

The Melbourne Age newspaper has been running a program in relation to the problems of the lower Yarra River and the way in which works might be carried out close to the city to restore access to that river and to make it a much more pleasing environment. Of course the problems of that river extend a long way further than those areas on which the Age newspaper is placing so much emphasis. It ought to be possible to spend money, for example, in the Northcote area on the perimeters of that river which would result in a substantial expansion of recreational opportunities for an area in which those opportunities are extremely limited. In terms of transport systems within that north-eastern corridor of Melbourne, substantial public works have been deferred by this Government which would save local government considerable amounts of money and distress.

Despite the fact that we have allowed major housing developments to occur in that corridor, particularly centred around Mill Park and that we have built a major university, La Trobe University, and although it has been agreed for a very long time that the tram line ought to be extended beyond Preston, at least as far as La Trobe University and certainly to the Mill Park housing development and the associated Preston Institute of Technology, that work has not developed. That extremely important piece of work could be carried out. It would expand employment opportunities and would reduce the enormous pressure of traffic on Preston and on the city of Northcote. Both those cities would regard that work as having extremely high priority in terms of saving them expenditures that are necessary for them in relation to the maintenance of roads and dealing with the traffic blight.

Similarly, there is an enormous potential for expansion of social and welfare services, an area in which unemployment is extremely high, in which there is an aging population and in which there are above average levels of people dependent upon social security benefits. I certainly would not regret the possibility of local government developing further in terms of health and welfare services. It seems to me that that is the scale at which those services ought to be delivered. Why is it that local government historically has been so much associated with the cost of infrastructure? The reason for that is clearly that local government has been dominated by the interests of real estate agents, local businessmen and industrialists.

The works that have been carried out by local government have, particularly in the inner suburbs of Melbourne and in cities such as Northcote, invariably been geared towards the interests of industry and very rarely been geared towards the interests of the residential population. That neglect, which has taken place over a very long period, now at a time of deindustrialisation in the inner suburbs of Melbourne, presents enormous problems to local government both to catch up in terms of the neglect of basic services existing in the past and to deal with the massive problems of unemployment which are the result of the decline of the small industries and the small firms which are characteristic of that area. It is quite extraordinary for this Government to suggest that it is any way at all interested in the concerns of small business and small scale industry. Any one who represents an electorate in which those kinds of industries are dominant knows that they have been ravaged in the past four years and that hundreds and perhaps thousands of jobs have been lost in cities like Northcote and Preston because of the recessionary policies of this Government.

Of course I support the proposition that local government ought to get 2 per cent and will get 2 per cent of tax revenue. I believe that local government provides the framework for tackling a whole range of problems, some of which exist in my electorate but others of which are present in the electorates of most of the members of this Parliament. I believe that we, as a Parliament, ought to be fostering devolution and we ought to be seeking to build stronger structures at the lowest possible level. This Government, as the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) has suggested, has simply seen the problems of local government and cities in terms of the flow of funds. It has been extremely biased about where the money goes.
Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

talk.start.para: -The assertion made by the honourable member for Batman (Mr Howe) that this Government is not interested in small business is just so much nonsense and I am sure that there is not a person in this nation who believes those sorts of comments, particularly coming as they do from the left wing of the Australian Labor Party. With the passing of this Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Amendment Bill we will witness another election commitment or promise made in 1977 being fulfilled. The election pledge was that local government's share of personal income tax would be increased from the then figure of 1.52 per cent to 2 per cent in the life of this Government. In 1977-78, and again in 1978-79 because there was no increase in the figure of 1.52 per cent during the first year that this Government was in office, the 1.52 per cent applied. We saw an increase in 1979-80 to 1.75 per cent, and of course the promise is being fulfilled now in 1980-81 with the 2 per cent of personal income tax flowing to local government.

speech.para: I want to examine the consistency of the Fraser Government in following through its federalism policy because there are many arms to this policy. It was announced prior to the 1975 election and it has been implemented in stages. First, there was the States (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act which provided for 33.6 per cent of personal income tax collections to flow to the States. This figure has since been increased to 39.8 per cent. Secondly, in stage two the Commonwealth allowed the States either to make a surcharge on their population if they believed that more work should be carried out in their State or, if they felt that the population should receive a rebate, to give a rebate to their residents.

The other part of Fraser federalism was that local government would share in the Commonwealth Government's personal income tax collections. I want to examine the benefits that have flowed to local government since Fraser federalism came into being. I think that one of the greatest benefits that has flowed to local government is really not connected with the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Amendment Bill. Inflation has been reduced from close to 20 per cent under the Whitlam Government to around 10 per cent today. This reduction, of course, has been of immense benefit to local government as, indeed, it has been to all sections of our community.

Secondly, tax sharing arrangements brought benefits to all local government authorities. Not only has the percentage of personal tax collections been increased, but also there has been a growth tax provision. The total personal tax collections have increased. Thirdly, these are untied grants that enable local authorities to plan decisively. Previously, assistance to local authorities was fragmented. With Regional Employment Development Schemes, area improvement programs and the like, local authorities were scrambling for funds and did not know whether they were receiving their full entitlement.

How much will local government receive under this Bill? The estimate for 1 980-8 1 of 2 per cent of personal income tax collections will provide $303m. Last year the figure was $22 1.74m. The additional $81m represents an increase of 36 per cent. A question that is often posed to me is: When will local authorities receive these payments? Payment could be made in early August. However, actual payment will depend on the State Grants Commissions. There should be no delay in payments to local authorities, as many are relying on the funds to carry out valuable and important capital works in their shires and cities. I wish to make a comparison between what is being done by the Commonwealth in the way of assistance to local government and what is happening insofar as the States are concerned. Some State governments give little or no assistance to local authorities and leave them to finance their capital works and services from their own revenue raising.

The position varies from State to State. However, I will take my own state of Queensland as an example. The State Government gives subsidies to local authorities for capital works. They range from no subsidy for some types of works and up to 50 per cent for others. The vast majority of projects undertaken in Queensland by local government attracts a subsidy of 15 per cent or 20 per cent. Of course, this subsidy is tied. It is a specific amount for specific types of work. On the other hand, if we make a comparison with the money that will flow to local government under this Bill, we find that the grants will be untied and that local government can do exactly what it wishes with the funds it receives.

The next point I wish to examine is what happens to the $300m. The apportionment of the $300m is undertaken by the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth Grants Commission has been responsible for determining the percentage that flows to each State. Once the States have been informed of their allocations, it is the task of the State local government grants commissions to allocate the funds to individual local authorities. Questions are often asked of members- indeed, I have had them asked of me- as to whether allocations are fair and whether local authorities are satisfied with the share they receive. Some local authorities are certainly unhappy with the allocation of funds that they receive. I wish to make it quite clear that it is not the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government to allocate funds to individual local authority areas. I believe that local authorities must be vocal if they believe that they are not receiving a fair deal at the hands of their local government grants commissions.

Some local authorities, at least in Queensland, are reluctant to speak out when dissatisfied with what they receive. I believe that they are reluctant to do so because they are fearful that the Queensland Government will mark them and that they will suffer financially in the handouts that may come from that Government at some future time. The fear of the Queensland Government is an indication of the dictatorial approach of that Government. Local authorities should be able to speak out clearly and critically, if they feel that is necessary, without fear of recriminations. This is not necessarily the case. Queensland's local authorities must stand firmly and ensure that the Queensland Government is fair and open in all its dealing with them.

It is interesting to note that of total public expenditures in 1977-78 the Federal Government expended some 47 per cent, State governments 46 per cent and local government 7 per cent. Surely these percentages must dispel thoughts that the Commonwealth has a bottomless pit of funds from which to draw. The people of this nation must realise that, although this Government collects the major portion of taxes, it does not spend all of it. Some 39.8 per cent of personal income tax goes straight to the States in an untied form. Frequently, calls by State governments for the Commonwealth to increase expenditure are politically dishonest. State governments are powerful. They expend 46 per cent of all public moneys expended by the three levels of government. They have the capacity to raise extra revenue if they so desire. Therefore, they should shoulder more responsibility instead of palming off the blame to the Commonwealth.

I next examine the level of local government rates and charges. Often it is said that local government rates are far too high. In terms of value for money the clear answer as to whether rates are too high in most local government areas is no. Generally speaking, local government is efficient. Certainly this is the case in my own State of Queensland. Where can the capital cost assets and services provided by local government be matched? Where for $300, $400 or perhaps $500 annually can people, depending on where they live, get roads, drainage, parks, gardens, water supply, sewage treatment, garbage collection, library services, child care centres, certain health services and so on? The cost amounts to $6 to $ 10 a week for each property or each family. Let us compare that rate with the cost for the supply of electricity which can run to $200 to $300 annually and that, it must be remembered, is for one commodity.

This 2 per cent of personal income tax from the Commonwealth is purely some assistance to local government. I think it has to be emphasised that in no way is it intended to replace the major revenue base of local government. Local government must continue to charge ratepayers in accordance with services it provides. Cries that ratepayers cannot pay increases are so much nonsense. Councillors and aldermen who have sympathetic ears should think again. It is within the province and power of a local authority to adjust individual payment of rates by pensioners and disadvantaged persons who may be having difficulty in meeting higher rate payments. These people need not be priced out of their homes as rates rise. Local authorities must bring equity to these people by rate remissions. Some elected representatives in local government want to see massive increases in the amount of funds flowing from the Commonwealth. I say this to those people: Governments that spend the money should suffer any odium that flows from raising it. There is always a price for autonomy and independence, and local government must face up to its responsibilities in raising revenue.

Concern has been expressed to me that personal income tax may not remain the main source of Commonwealth revenue. Personal income tax may fall or remain static while indirect taxes increase. This depends on government policy of the day and of course would affect revenue to local government as indeed it would to the States. This issue is often raised- and rightly so- by people involved in local government. I raised the matter with the Minister for Education (Mr Fife), who is at the table, when he was Minister Assisting the Prime Minister in Federal Affairs. I believe that the reply he gave me ought to become part of the record, because in it there is protection for local government. The Minister wrote to me on this matter on 4 December 1978. I wish to quote a couple of paragraphs from this letter, as follows:

quote.para: I am aware of the concern of local government that personal income tax may not remain the major source of Commonwealth revenue and that such a development would have implications for the tax sharing arrangements. In the course of negotiating the tax sharing arrangements with the States, this matter was also raised by Premiers. The Commonwealth acknowledged the Premiers ! concern and agreed on the need to provide flexibility in the arrangements to meet such a situation. The Points of Understanding agreed between the Commonwealth and the States, which are included in Chapter II of Budget Paper No. 7-

speech.para: That was Budget Paper No. 7 of 1 977-78-

quote.para: Include provisions for such flexibility:

The Commonwealth has no formal agreement with local government equivalent to the Points of Understanding. However, local government's tax sharing entitlement is defined in the legislation as a percentage of a base amount on which the States' tax sharing entitlement is calculated. As a result, any changes in the nature of the base amount for the States, which would be agreed with the States, would be applied automatically to local government's tax sharing entitlement.
In any event, if the Commonwealth was to proceed with a new taxation policy that disadvantaged local government, appropriate amendments would be introduced to the tax sharing arrangements.

speech.para: I think that clearly indicates that there is a protection for local government should the Commonwealth decide to change its revenue raising from direct taxes to more indirect taxes. I wish to raise one further matter; that is the amount which is presently allowed as tax deductible expenditure for income tax purposes. At present the figure is $300 and I believe that it should be raised to at least $400. In effect many taxpayers at present are paying personal taxation on a tax and while local government rates rise without compensatory increases in the maximum deductible figure of $300, of course the situation will worsen.
Finally, I want to raise a matter in relation to the report of the House of Representatives

Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation entitled 'The Commonwealth Government and the Urban Environment' which was presented to this House in May 1978. At this point the Government has yet to respond to that report. I draw the attention of the House particularly to recommendations Nos. 14 and 15. Recommendation No. 14 deals with the nonpayment of general rates by the Commonwealth Government and by State governments. Recommendation No. 15 refers to the noncompliance by the States and by the Commonwealth with local government by-laws. Recommendation No. 14 states:

quote.para: The Commonwealth Government recognise explicitly its obligation to compensate municipalities for loss of general rate revenue as a consequence of Commonwealth Government immunity in respect of Crown property.

speech.para: There is a section (b) to that recommendation but the pertinent one is section (a) which I have just quoted. What is happening in effect is that many local authorities around this nation are being paid no general rates on large tracts of land held by the Commonwealth or by the State. In the inquiry to which I have referred evidence was taken from a number of local authorities and from the Local Government Association of New South Wales. Of course, in the course of that evidence the Association, no doubt pointing out the most blatant cases, cited the municipality of South Sydney which lost a substantial portion of its rates when the Leyland company sold its complex to the Department of Defence. That municipality suffered a further loss of rate revenue as a result of the extension of Telecom facilities and of the provision of new workshops and a container depot in the Waterloo industrial area. It suffered further because of the expansion of Sydney University and several schools in the area. Of course, there was additional vacant land owned by the Housing Commission on which it received no general rates. It was stated further that the rate revenue lost on that Commonwealth and State land in that municipality amounted to 1 5 per cent of the total rate revenue of that Council. I believe that, although one can argue that there are mechanisms to bring equality to that local authority through the State Grants Commission, there ought to be a separate Commonwealth amount allocated by the Grants Commission to local authorities which have large tracts of land held in Commonwealth and State ownership on which no rates are received by those local authorities. Finally -

talk.start.para: - Hooray!

- It would appear from some of the cries from the Opposition that it has little or no interest in this Bill and in the funds which flow to local government. This is an important measure and ought to be treated as such by all members of this House. The final point I make is in relation to Commonwealth departments and instrumentalities complying with State and local government by-laws and regulations. Too frequently we find that both Commonwealth Government departments and instrumentalities and State Government departments and instrumentalities are not abiding by the regulations of local authorities. I believe that they ought to abide by those regulations. Of course, in many instances regulations are approved by the State governments and those governments see fit to flout the regulations.

debate.para: Plant Breeders' Rights- East Timor- Defence Motion (by Mr Fife) proposed: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: -I raise in this House tonight a matter which should be of great concern to the National Country Party. The honourable member for Angas is umming and aahing opposite, so obviously it is not.
- Angas has been eliminated.

- The seat of Angas has been eliminated; Wakefield might end up being eliminated also. The matter I raise tonight is a vital one to certain sections of my electorate. I refer to the very vexed matter of plant breeders' rights, a matter about which members of the National Country Party and the Liberal Party of Australia obviously know nothing. I will explain it to them. Plant breeders' rights or, as it is commonly called, plant variety rights protection, basically is a system of patents.
- Haven't you read the draft legislation?

-I point that out in case the honourable member for Eden-Monaro wants to know. Obviously he knows little about the matter, even though he supposedly represents a country electorate. It is a system of patents applicable to newly developed cultivars used commercially in agricultural, horticultural and pastoral industries. This must be of interest to hourable members opposite. Plant variety protection legislation confers on individual plant breeders or organisations employing them the right to levy and to collect royalties from the user end of the new cultivars which have been developed. These rights which are conferred by plant variety protection legislation- I hope that one day it will be introduced into this Parliamentusually extends over a period of 15 to 18 years in other countries and, in general, remains operative for the same period as patent rights remain operative in the country of origin. It offers one of the main benefits accruing to the Australian primary producer.

speech.para: I am forced to speak on behalf of Australian primary producers because unfortunately the Country Party is not representing them tonight. I would like some members of the Country Party to come into the House and speak in defence of their people. Because they have not done so, at this hour of 20 minutes past 12 1 have to speak on behalf of country people.

One of the main benefits accruing to Australian primary producers from plant variety protection legislation would be the guarantee that the world 's best varieties of all types of crops and pastures could be imported- naturally subject to certain plant quarantine legislation- and made available for general use on the basis that the selling price would include a small royalty payable in due course to the originator of the particular new cultivar. The honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Giles) is out of the chamber when I am referring to wine grapes. He walked out earlier. I mention also apples and certain ornamental species. Where is the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) and the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) when I am speaking about apples? They are not in this chamber when they should be here defending the apple growers of Tasmania. Where are they? They should be defending the apple growers of Tasmania, but they are not even in the chamber. It is only 20 minutes past 12 in the morning. Where are they? They are probably at home sleeping. Who has to get up in this chamber and defend these people? I have to. It should not be my role to do so. I am concerned tonight at the apparent inaction of certain members of the National Country Party; not all of them. There are some good members of the National Country Party, but not very many.

The whole trouble is this: There appears to be a real fear about what this plant variety rights Bill might do. Apparently certain parties with a vested interest in their own rights have got at the present Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon). The portfolio used to be Agriculture but this Minister does not know very much about agriculture. The present Minister for Primary Industry seems to have gone to water on this legislation. Why is it that this Bill, which was promised to the plant breeders and which would improve the standard of our horticulture and agriculture, has not been introduced by the Government? Is it a fact that the plant variety rights Bill has been excluded from the current parliamentary session by order of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on the grounds that it was not considered to be of sufficient importance to warrant introduction during this parliamentary session? The Prime Minister is not even here to answer that charge. I would like to ask the Minister for Primary Industry about the present position regarding this Bill. talk.start.para: - I do not want to keep people out of bed for too long but I was prompted to speak in the first place by the basic lack of knowledge of the honourable member for Banks (Mr Martin) about plant breeders' rights and in the second place by his basic lack of knowledge of the reasons why a Bill has not been introduced into this House. In the first place, I must say that I was surprised that a member of the Australian Labor Party had not been following the Professor Ted Wheelwright line that the plant breeders' rights legislation, if it ever comes into the place, would be a bad thing. In fact in an Australian Broadcasting Commission program called Notes on the News which is broadcast at 1.23 every afternoon, Professor Wheelwright put forward the view that if we ever had plant breeders' rights legislation in this country it would inevitably lead to a monopoly situation whereby, through a conglomeration of companies being involved in the breeding of plant varieties, people would be excluded from having access to the wide range of plant breeds that they should have access to. He also said that if that should happen there would also be an exclusion of many of the genetic strains we now have access to because it would be in the interest of monopolies to eliminate those genes.

speech.para: On the Ted Wheelwright line, I point out, as has been pointed out by the honourable member, that plant breeders' rights are an important matter to go on the legislative program. It is not possible for the genes to be eliminated. For instance, the British are at present setting up a bank of genes, as has the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in Australia, to ensure that the genes available in plant varieties that have been gathered from a number of countries throughout the world will be preserved so that in the case of a hybrid variety contracting problems with respect to nonresistance to disease the genes that have existed for thousands of years can still be called on. Plant breeders' rights will be a reality. It is important to remember why the reality will not have the effect of bringing about a monopoly situation which will exclude the genes.

Another reason why a monopoly situation will not arise in Australia if we establish plant breeders' rights is that if people who care to spend money on research to produce new varieties keep the rights to those varieties for a limited period of 10 years, we would hope that after that period they would have made a reasonable profit. Other people in the community would then also have free access to those varieties so that a monopoly situation could not arise. The reason the BUI has not been introduced until this stage is that some debate is still going on as to whether the European or the American model for the Bill should be introduced into Australia. The present thinking in the Department of Primary Industry is that the American model should come in. Because of the time allotted to speakers in the adjournment debate I am not able to go into all the details. We need a standardisation of the model wherein judgments can be made by experts as to what a plant breeder's right actually is. The American model goes into ways and means of deciding whether a patent is unique, as does the European model. It is important for us to decide which one to adopt. It is also important that we make the right decision. It is important not only to research jobs in Australia, our reputation and our exports of new genes and varieties but also -

talk.start.para: -I raise briefly once again the issue of East Timor, particularly Timorese refugees. I refer to an article by Peter Rodgers in the National Times of last Sunday entitled 'Gate shut on 200 refugees from Timor'. The article states:

quote.para: Indonesia appears to have slammed the door on further departures from East Timor of people included in the Australia-East Timor family reunion scheme. In doing so it has dashed the hopes of more than 200 East Timorese still waiting to join family members in Australia under the scheme.

speech.para: It is quite clear that the Indonesian Government has now dishonoured the agreement it entered into with the Australian Government in 1978 to allow 600 refugees to come to Australia. Peter Rodgers in his article suggests that the reason for this- I think he may be correct- is the extreme sensitivity of the Indonesian Government towards allowing to come to Australia people who may be able to talk about what has happened in East Timor over the past four years. Fewer than half the number of people whom it was promised would be able to come to Australia have actually come. Very few of them are indigenous Timorese. It would seem to me that, as a Parliament, we will have to continue to press this issue. It seems quite incredible that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Peacock) who is making very strong speeches in relation to the situation in western Asia is quite clearly unable to stand up to his opposite number in Djakarta. He is quite unable to exert any serious pressure on the Indonesian Government with respect to a situation which is relatively minor in terms of the kinds of problems that exist in the world. Literally, we are talking about no more than 200 or 300 people but the Australian Government is simply not prepared to press this issue as strongly as it should be pressed. I would argue that it is being extremely weak. It is simply not creating the kind of noise that needs to be created.

Peter Rodgers points out in his article that there is developing within Australia a very strong anti-Indonesian sentiment because of this issue. People are getting the message that the Indonesian Government is much tougher, in terms of people- in many ways because they have children and wives in this country- than, for example, the Soviet Union has ever been in relation to Jewish people in that country. It will not allow a family reunion in the case of 200 or 300 people whose kids are already in this country and are separated from their families. I put it to honourable members that the Minister for Foreign Affairs is being gutless on this question and that the Government is being gutless because it is not prepared to use a strong voice for fear of producing a reaction in Indonesia. The Government's policy of handling Indonesia with kid gloves will be absolutely counter-productive. It will develop in this country a very strong antiIndonesian feeling. People will not want to cooperate with Indonesia or be sympathetic to it. That will flow from the fact that they see the Indonesian Government as incredibly insensitive on this issue. I believe that they will see the Australian Government as being extremely weak.

I raise this issue and will continue to do so because I believe that when the Government is talking about taking strong action in the Foreign Affairs area it ought to be able to sort out what is, relatively speaking, a minor problem such as this. If it cannot do so, why is it talking about involvement in the Indian Ocean and Arabian Sea, or about extending the ANZUS Treaty to cover a vast new ocean. It cannot even cope with a minor problem 200 or 300 refugees.
