talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 October 1 979:

item.para: 1 ) Has his attention been drawn to a report by the University of New South Wales entitled Lead Burden of Sydney School Children which raises serious concern about elevated lead burdens in 1,500 school children.
Does the report show that 42 per cent of children at a Mascot school and 22 per cent of children at a Mosman school had levels of over 25 micrograms of lead per 100 mis of blood.

Have overseas studies indicated that children with elevated lead levels in their milk teeth perform significantly worse on a range of IQ and other neuropsychological tests and have poorer concentration, oral skills and classroom behaviour.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: 1 ) Yes, I am aware of the findings of the report, as it was financed in part by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH & MRC) and has been closely studied by my Department.

answer.para: I am, however, unable to determine the source of the figure of 1,500 for the number of school children with elevated blood lead levels quoted by the honourable member.
The survey itself was conducted on 1,200 children, not all of whom had blood lead values of concern.

item.para: The report, in fact, shows that 42 per cent of children at the Mascot school and 26 per cent (not the 22 per cent quotes by the honourable member) of children at the Mosman school had blood lead levels above 25 ug/ 100 ml blood in the spring 1974 survey. The corresponding figures in the Autumn 1975 survey were 18 per cent and 14 per cent respectively. 1 1.5 per cent of all the Sydney schoolchildren in the Spring survey and 3.3 per cent in the Autumn survey had blood lead levels above 30 ug.

A recent US study (Needleman et al, 'Deficits in psychologic and classroom performance of children with elevated dentine lead levels', N. Eng. J. Med., 300: 689-95, 1979) showed that children with high lead levels scored significantly less well on the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children (revised) than those with low lead levels. The study concluded that lead exposure, at doses below those producing symptoms severe enough to be diagnosed clinically, appeared to be associated with neuropsychological deficits that may have interfered with classroom performance.

(a) Screening of Australian children has been considered by my Department and the question of lead metabolism in children has been referred to the Nutrition Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The concern of health authorities in relation to the general population is the reduction of lead in forms which can be inhaled, absorbed or ingested into human tissue. The NH & MRC has recently denned appropriate goals which will assist in consideration of the wider implications relating to lead in petrol. Positive measures have been taken to reduce air pollution from motor vehicles by the definition by the NH & MRC of appropriate goals for lead and photochemical oxidants. The details of these recommendations are as follows:

answer.para: Criteria for atmospheric lead

Council noted that on present knowledge, lead had no essential role or beneficial effect for humans, and that the total body burden of lead, for persons not occupationally exposed, was derived mainly from food, air and water.
It is noted that recent investigations had indicated that lead levels lower than those previously thought to be significant may now be producing adverse health effects.

The contribution to the total body lead burden by food and other ingested substances remained of concern in spite of efforts made by Council over many years to reduce lead uptake from the many varied sources. Further efforts to effect overall reductions were considered essential. Having considered extensive Australian and overseas data, Council recommended that 30 ug lead/ 100 ml blood in the Australian population be taken to represent a level of concern. The maintenance of blood lead levels below this figure would ensure adequate protection from the potentially harmful effects of lead, particularly in the more susceptible groups such as children and pregnant women. A geometric mean lead level of 15 ug/100 ml blood would ensure that the majority of the population at risk would not exceed the recommended level of concern.

Council accepted that 20 per cent of the total body lead burden could be contributed by lead in air, particularly in areas subject to heavy pollution, and that, consequently, of the geometric mean level of 15 ug/100 ml of blood, up to 3 ug/ 100 ml of blood could be attributed to lead derived from the air. It also accepted that a general relationship of 1:2 between air lead (ug Pb/m3) and blood lead (ug Pb/ 100 ml) was appropriate.

In accepting the above air/blood relationship, Council recommended that the maximum permissible level of lead in air in the urban environment should be 1.5 ug/m³ averaged over 3 calendar months, the level of 1.5 ug Pb/m1 being an average 3-month level calculated on the basis of 15 x 24-hour samples collected over a 3-month period taken at 6 day intervals thereby ensuring that samples were collected on different days of each week.
It recommended that State health authorities be urged to institute programs directed towards compliance with these recommended goals.
Council stressed that goals for lead and similar toxic substances remain subject to review with the passage of time and in the light of future medical and technological advances.
Levels for photochemical oxidants
Council recognised the need to safeguard the health of the Australian population from the potential hazards resulting from raised photochemical oxidant levels to which they may be exposed.

It examined all available reports and literature, and considered that there was sufficient scientific information available to allow the determination of a photochemical oxidant level, based on human health effects, defined by adopting ozone as an indicator of the degree of photochemical oxidant formation.

Council therefore considered that, as a long term goal, the number of days in a year, with maximum hourly average ozone concentrations above 240 ug/m³ (0.12 ppm) should not exceed one. It recommended that action designed to attain this goal should be implemented as soon as possible.

It recognised that authorities responsible for the design and implementation of control strategies to achieve this goal will need to take account of the statistical distribution of ozone concentrations.
Council also recommended that a public warning should be given when ozone levels are expected to rise above 500 ug/m³ (0.25 ppm) to enable appropriate precautionary measures to be taken.
It stressed that the goals for ozone and related air pollutants should be subject to review in the light of new medical and technical knowledge.

The amounts included in the respective States' base amounts were:

In succeeding years up to and including 1975-76, the financial assistance grant for each State was determined by increasing the grant payable to it in the preceding year by reference to the formula described above. In 1976-77, the system of financial assistance grants was replaced by the present system of tax sharing; under these arrangements the States are entitled, subject to certain guarantees, to receive annually a specified share of net personal income taxation collections by the Commonwealth. During the period 1976-77 to 1979-80, the States are guaranteed that their entitlements will not be less in a year than the amount which would have been yielded in that year by the financial assistance grants formula. item.para: Pay-roll tax, except for pay-roll tax in Commonwealth mainlaind Territories, has been a State matter since I September 1971. An example of relevant State legislation enacted in 197 1 was the New South Wales Pay-roll Tax Act, 1971 which exempted from the tax all wages paid by councils except those paid in respect of business undertakings or activities- Under the Act business activities included those connected with the supply of electricity or gas, water supply, sewerage, the conduct of abattoirs, of public food markets, of parking stations, of cemeteries, of crematoriums or of hostels or of any other activity that is a trading activity within the meaning of Part XVII of the (N.S.W.) Local Government Act, 1919.

As explained in the answer to Part ( 1 ), payments in relation to exemption of 'non-business' activities of local authorities from State pay-roll were made by the Commonwealth by way of notional aggregate amounts which were added to States' financial assistance grants. Payments were not made in respect of individual bodies or organisations. The benefit gained by each body or organisation each year has been the amount of pay-roll tax it would otherwise have been required to pay.
